dimensions: plate (sheet trimmed to plate): 30.5 × 47.2 cm (12 × 18 9/16 in.)
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund, and gift of the Department of Art and Archaeology in honor of Professor Patricia Fortini Brown
markings: Watermark: Armorial bearing shield with six-pointed star and illegible
inscribed:
Inscribed in plate on book, upper right corner: Baccius / Bandi: / nellus / inuentz

Inscribed in plate below sleeping dog, lower center: Roma Petrus Paulus Palumbus formis

makers.displaymaker: Published by Pietro Paolo Palombo, Italian, active ca. 1564–1584

texts.textentryhtml: This engraving was commissioned by sculptor Baccio Bandinelli, Michelangelo’s archrival in Florence, as a form of self-advertisement in which the artist’s studio is conceived as an academic training ground. Bandinelli, standing at the extreme right, and adorned with the badge of the knighthood of Santiago, observes a group of fashionably dressed male students who are shown drawing, reading, and conversing. The skeletons, skulls, and plaster casts allude to the important role of anatomy and classical antiquity in the education of the artist in sixteenth-century Italy. The dissemination of prints from Northern Europe is reflected in the poses of the cat and the dog, appropriated from two engravings by Albrecht Dürer.

bibliography.boilertext: Laura Giles, Lia Markey, Claire Van Cleave, et. al., Italian Master Drawings from the Princeton University Art Museum, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2014).
bibliography.citation: Laura Giles, Lia Markey, Claire Van Cleave, et. al., Italian Master Drawings from the Princeton University Art Museum, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2014)., p. 25, fig. 9.1

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2010," Record of the Princeton University Art Museum 70 (2011): p. 69-110.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2010," Record of the Princeton University Art Museum 70 (2011): p. 69-110., p. 108, p. 110 (illus.)
